message_1: In a store, there are 8 different types of fruits. If a customer wants to buy a total of 20 fruits, how many ways can the customer choose the fruits if they want to buy at least 2 of each type? (Hint: Use Multinomial coefficients)
message_2:
Since the customer wants to buy at least 2 of each type of fruit, we can start by giving them 2 fruits of each type. This means they have already chosen 2 * 8 = 16 fruits. Now, they need to choose 4 more fruits from the 8 types.

We can use the stars and bars method to solve this problem. We have 4 "stars" (fruits) to distribute among 8 "bars" (fruit types). To do this, we need to place 3 dividers among the 4 stars. This will give us 7 positions in total (4 stars + 3 dividers).

We can use the multinomial coefficient formula to calculate the number of ways to choose the fruits:

C(n + k - 1, k - 1) = C(7, 3)

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3! * (7 - 3)!)

C(7, 3) = 7! / (3! * 4!)

C(7, 3) = 5040 / (6 * 24)

C(7, 3) = 5040 / 144

C(7, 3) = 35

So, there are 35 ways for the customer to choose the fruits if they want to buy at least 2 of each type.
